<|ref|>title<|/ref|><|det|>[[94, 194, 220, 209]]<|/det|>
# MATHEMATICS  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[94, 216, 388, 233]]<|/det|>
Paper 7 Probability & Statistics 2 (S2)  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[94, 259, 455, 304]]<|/det|>
Additional Materials: Answer Booklet/Paper Graph Paper List of Formulae (MF9)  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[94, 320, 390, 338]]<|/det|>
READ THESE INSTRUCTIONS FIRST  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[94, 351, 828, 367]]<|/det|>
If you have been given an Answer Booklet, follow the instructions on the front cover of the Booklet.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[94, 368, 722, 384]]<|/det|>
Write your Centre number, candidate number and name on all the work you hand in.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[94, 384, 325, 400]]<|/det|>
Write in dark blue or black pen.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[94, 400, 497, 416]]<|/det|>
You may use a soft pencil for any diagrams or graphs.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[94, 416, 601, 433]]<|/det|>
Do not use staples, paper clips, highlighters, glue or correction fluid.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[94, 448, 284, 463]]<|/det|>
Answer all the questions.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[94, 463, 907, 495]]<|/det|>
Give non- exact numerical answers correct to 3 significant figures, or 1 decimal place in the case of angles in degrees, unless a different level of accuracy is specified in the question.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[94, 494, 590, 510]]<|/det|>
The use of an electronic calculator is expected, where appropriate.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[94, 510, 606, 526]]<|/det|>
You are reminded of the need for clear presentation in your answers.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[94, 540, 606, 556]]<|/det|>
At the end of the examination, fasten all your work securely together.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[94, 556, 756, 572]]<|/det|>
The number of marks is given in brackets [] at the end of each question or part question.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[94, 572, 440, 588]]<|/det|>
The total number of marks for this paper is 50.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[94, 588, 907, 619]]<|/det|>
Questions carrying smaller numbers of marks are printed earlier in the paper, and questions carrying larger numbers of marks later in the paper.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 73, 97, 92]]<|/det|>
<label>1</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 73, 875, 92]]<|/det|>
A random sample of 80 values of a variable \(X\) is taken and these values are summarised below.

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[331, 100, 668, 120]]<|/det|>
\[n = 80\qquad \Sigma x = 150.2\qquad \Sigma x^2 = 820.24\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 127, 920, 161]]<|/det|>
Calculate unbiased estimates of the population mean and variance of \(X\) and hence find a \(95\%\) confidence interval for the population mean of \(X\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[892, 144, 920, 163]]<|/det|>
<mark>[6]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 190, 94, 208]]<|/det|>
<label>2</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 187, 920, 255]]<|/det|>
A traffic officer notes the speeds of vehicles as they pass a certain point. In the past the mean of these speeds has been \(62.3 \mathrm{km} \mathrm{h}^{- 1}\) and the standard deviation has been \(10.4 \mathrm{km} \mathrm{h}^{- 1}\). A speed limit is introduced, and following this, the mean of the speeds of 75 randomly chosen vehicles passing the point is found to be \(59.9 \mathrm{km} \mathrm{h}^{- 1}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[128, 268, 154, 286]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 268, 920, 301]]<|/det|>
Making an assumption that should be stated, test at the \(2\%\) significance level whether the mean speed has decreased since the introduction of the speed limit.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[892, 285, 920, 303]]<|/det|>
<mark>[6]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[123, 314, 153, 332]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[158, 313, 776, 332]]<|/det|>
Explain whether it was necessary to use the Central Limit theorem in part (i).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[892, 314, 920, 332]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 361, 97, 380]]<|/det|>
<label>3</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 361, 920, 395]]<|/det|>
The waiting time, \(T\) weeks, for a particular operation at a hospital has probability density function given by

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[343, 394, 653, 437]]<|/det|>
\[\mathrm{f}(t) = \left\{ \begin{array}{ll}\frac{1}{2500} (100t - t^3) & 0\leqslant t\leqslant 10,\\ 0 & \mathrm{otherwise}. \end{array} \right.\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[128, 453, 156, 472]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[160, 453, 435, 472]]<|/det|>
Given that \(\mathrm{E}(T) = \frac{16}{3}\), find \(\mathrm{Var}(T)\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 454, 920, 472]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[123, 485, 153, 504]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 485, 920, 520]]<|/det|>
10% of patients have to wait more than \(n\) weeks for their operation. Find the value of \(n\), giving your answer correct to the nearest integer.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 501, 920, 518]]<|/det|>
<mark>[5]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 547, 94, 565]]<|/det|>
<label>4</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 546, 920, 596]]<|/det|>
Goals scored by Femchester United occur at random with a constant average of 1.2 goals per match. Goals scored against Femchester United occur independently and at random with a constant average of 0.9 goals per match.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[126, 610, 153, 628]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[158, 609, 764, 628]]<|/det|>
Find the probability that in a randomly chosen match involving Femchester,

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 636, 185, 653]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[196, 636, 425, 653]]<|/det|>
a total of 3 goals are scored,

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 636, 920, 655]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 660, 185, 678]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[196, 660, 598, 678]]<|/det|>
a total of 3 goals are scored and Femchester wins.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 660, 920, 678]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 691, 920, 724]]<|/det|>
The manager promises the Femchester players a bonus if they score at least 35 goals in the next 25 matches.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[123, 739, 153, 757]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 739, 593, 757]]<|/det|>
Find the probability that the players receive the bonus.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 737, 920, 756]]<|/det|>
<mark>[4]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[76, 73, 94, 92]]<|/det|>
<label>5</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 73, 885, 92]]<|/det|>
A fair six-sided die has faces numbered 1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6. The score on one throw is denoted by \(X\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[126, 104, 153, 123]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 104, 620, 123]]<|/det|>
Write down the value of \(\mathrm{E}(X)\) and show that \(\mathrm{Var}(X) = \frac{35}{12}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 104, 920, 123]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 135, 920, 201]]<|/det|>
Fayez has a six-sided die with faces numbered 1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6. He suspects that it is biased so that when it is thrown it is more likely to show a low number than a high number. In order to test his suspicion, he plans to throw the die 50 times. If the mean score is less than 3 he will conclude that the die is biased.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[123, 214, 153, 231]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 214, 458, 231]]<|/det|>
Find the probability of a Type I error.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 214, 920, 232]]<|/det|>
<mark>[5]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 244, 153, 262]]<|/det|>
<label>(iii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 244, 920, 276]]<|/det|>
With reference to this context, describe circumstances in which Fayez would make a Type II error.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 260, 920, 279]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[76, 306, 94, 324]]<|/det|>
<label>6</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 305, 920, 339]]<|/det|>
The lifetimes, in hours, of Longlive light bulbs and Enerlow light bulbs have the independent distributions \(\mathrm{N}(1020, 45^2)\) and \(\mathrm{N}(2800, 52^2)\) respectively.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[128, 354, 153, 371]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 354, 920, 386]]<|/det|>
Find the probability that the total of the lifetimes of 5 randomly chosen Longlive bulbs is less than 5200 hours.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 369, 920, 387]]<|/det|>
<mark>[4]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[123, 400, 153, 418]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 400, 920, 433]]<|/det|>
Find the probability that the lifetime of a randomly chosen Enerlow bulb is at least 3 times that of a randomly chosen Longlive bulb.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 418, 920, 435]]<|/det|>
<mark>[6]

<|ref|>title<|/ref|><|det|>[[432, 75, 564, 90]]<|/det|>
